In view of the Note*at P.Z.5314/33 there seems no objection to basing the rate of income-tax at Aden upon Indian Income-tax Laws, with the addition of such modifications as may be thought necessary. This will presumably cover the point raised by Colonel Reilly in the first paragraph of the portion of his letter which is at P.Z.3608/36. The question whether officers should pay British or Aden income-tax of H.M.G.’s contribution does not appear to be our concern. The question vfoether Officers serving under the Civil and Political Administration should pay British Income Tax depends on the decision with the regard to the framing of the Budget. If all officers are paid from the Aden Budget, and a grant-in-aid received from His Majesty 1 s Government the officers would be liable to Aden Income Tax and. not to British Income Tax. At present the Government of India receive an agreed sum of x.500 from His Majesty’s Govemnent towards income tax on the salaries of Military and Air Force personnel and Political Officers, who are exempted from Indian Income Tax. A similar amount may be expected from His Majesty’s Goverment after the separation. Point 1 . Income Tax . I consider that the present Income Tax rates should be continued, as proposed, under an Aden Ordinance to be made by the new Aden Crown Colony Government. A point for consideration is the levy of the present surcharge on Income Tax and Super Tax which was introduced by the Government of India as an emergency measure in 1931, and which has subsequently been reduced from 25 to 8 1/3 per dent. If this surcharge is to be continued by the Government of India next year, I consider that it should be continued in Aden also, but that its abolition in Aden should be considered when it is abolished in India.i I 5575 Financial Secretary, x—v You may care to see the papers below. titleInfo.title: Coll 1/44 'Aden. Changes in civil administration in the event of separation from India: rate of income tax'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in chronological order from the rear to the front of the file

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 9; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence between the Aden Chief Commissioner (Bernard Reilly) and the India Office, regarding income tax arrangements following the transfer of the civil administration of Aden to the Colonial Office. It is suggested that Aden adopt the Indian Income-tax act, with any necessary modifications.
